$2I = x\sqrt{...} + a^2 \ln|x+\sqrt{...}|$. Divide by 2.

related_concepts.name: Integration by Parts
related_concepts.definition: $\\int u dv = uv - \\int v du$.

subject: Math
title: Integral of sqrt(x^2 - a^2)
description: Standard form. Note the negative sign in the second term.
derivation:
Similar to $x^2+a^2$, use Parts or substitution $x = a \sec \theta$.
Using Parts:
$I = x\sqrt{x^2-a^2} - \int \frac{x^2}{\sqrt{x^2-a^2}} dx$.
Split $x^2 = (x^2-a^2) + a^2$.
$I = x\sqrt{...} - (I + a^2 \int \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-a^2}} dx)$.
$2I = x\sqrt{...} - a^2 \ln|x+\sqrt{...}|$.

related_concepts.name: Hyperbolic Substitution
related_concepts.definition: Alternative method using $x = a \cosh t$.

subject: Math
title: Rational Trig Integral
description: Universal substitution for rational trigonometric integrals.
derivation:
Use half-angle formulas:
$\sin x = \frac{2t}{1+t^2}, \quad \cos x = \frac{1-t^2}{1+t^2}, \quad dx = \frac{2dt}{1+t^2}$.
The integral converts to a rational algebraic integral:
$\int \frac{2dt}{a(2t) + b(1-t^2)}$.
This is a standard quadratic denominator form.

related_concepts.name: Weierstrass Substitution
related_concepts.definition: The technique of using $\tan(x/2)$ to rationalize trigonometric integrals.

subject: Math
title: Area of Triangle
visual_data: \Delta = \frac{1}{2} \left| \det \begin{pmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \right|
description: Absolute value of determinant gives area. If 0, points are collinear.
derivation:
From coordinate geometry formula:
Area $= \frac{1}{2} |x_1(y_2-y_3) + x_2(y_3-y_1) + x_3(y_1-y_2)|$.
Expanding the determinant along Column 1:
$x_1(y_2(1)-1(y_3)) - x_2(y_1(1)-1(y_3)) + x_3(y_1(1)-1(y_2))$.
This expansion matches the coordinate formula exactly.

related_concepts.name: Collinearity Condition
related_concepts.definition: Area = 0 implies the three points lie on a straight line.

subject: Math
title: Cramer's Rule (Unique Solution)
visual_data: D \neq 0 \implies x = D_x/D, y = D_y/D, z = D_z/D
description: Method to solve linear equations using determinants.
derivation:
System $AX = B$.
$x = \frac{|A_x|}{|A|}$ where $A_x$ replaces the x-column with constants vector B.
Geometric interpretation involving volumes of parallelepipeds spanned by column vectors.
If $D \neq 0$, the vectors are linearly independent, ensuring a unique solution.

related_concepts.name: Consistent System
related_concepts.definition: A system of equations that has at least one set of solutions.

subject: Math
title: Cramer's Rule (No Solution)
description: Condition for inconsistent system (Parallel planes).
derivation:
If $D=0$, the coefficient matrix is singular (planes normals are coplanar/parallel).
If any numerator determinant ($D_x, D_y, D_z$) is non-zero, it implies a contradiction (like $0 \cdot x = 5$).
Geometrically, this corresponds to parallel planes with no common intersection.

related_concepts.name: Inconsistent System
related_concepts.definition: A system of equations with no solution.

subject: Math
title: Cramer's Rule (Infinite Solutions)
description: Condition for dependent system (Coincident or intersecting in a line).
derivation:
All determinants zero implies $0 \cdot x = 0$.
This creates a dependent system where equations are multiples of each other or linear combinations.
Result is a line or plane of solutions (infinite points).
*Note: Exception exists for parallel planes, requiring Gaussian check.*

related_concepts.name: Dependent System
related_concepts.definition: System with infinite solutions where one equation can be derived from others.

subject: Math
title: Factor Theorem
description: Useful for factorizing determinants containing variables.
derivation:
Based on polynomial theory.
If substituting $x=a$ makes two rows or columns identical, the determinant value becomes zero.
Since determinant expansion is a polynomial, by Factor Theorem, $(x-a)$ must be a factor of $\Delta(x)$.
Example: If rows are $1, x, x^2$ and $1, y, y^2$, then $(x-y)$ is a factor.

related_concepts.name: Vandermonde Determinant
related_concepts.definition: Determinant with terms $x_i^j$, factors into $\Pi(x_i - x_j)$.

subject: Math
title: Parametric Tangent (Parabola)
description: Tangent to $y^2 = 4ax$ at point $(at^2, 2at)$.
derivation:
Equation of tangent at $(x_1, y_1)$ is $yy_1 = 2a(x+x_1)$.
Substitute parametric coords: $x_1 = at^2, y_1 = 2at$.
$y(2at) = 2a(x + at^2)$.
Divide by $2a$: $ty = x + at^2$.
Slope $m = 1/t$.

related_concepts.name: Focal Chord
related_concepts.definition: Chord passing through focus. Tangents at endpoints intersect at right angles on directrix.

subject: Math
title: Parametric Normal (Parabola)
description: Normal to $y^2 = 4ax$ at point $(at^2, 2at)$.
derivation:
Slope of tangent is $1/t$.
Slope of normal is $-t$.
Equation: $y - y_1 = m(x - x_1)$.
$y - 2at = -t(x - at^2)$.
$y = -tx + at^3 + 2at$.

related_concepts.name: Co-normal Points
related_concepts.definition: Three normals can be drawn from a point to a parabola; feet are co-normal points.

subject: Math
title: Chord of Contact
description: Chord joining points of contact of tangents from external point $(x_1, y_1)$.
derivation:
Same derivation as for Circle.
Let points of contact be A and B.
Tangent at A passes through P. Tangent at B passes through P.
Linear equation $T=0$ with respect to P is satisfied by both A and B.
Thus it represents line AB.
Formula for Parabola: $yy_1 = 2a(x+x_1)$.

related_concepts.name: Polar
related_concepts.definition: The line T=0 is the polar of point P (pole) with respect to the conic.

subject: Math
title: Chord with Midpoint
description: Equation of chord bisected at $(x_1, y_1)$.
derivation:
Let chord be $y-y_1 = m(x-x_1)$.
Intersects conic at A, B. $(x_1, y_1)$ is midpoint.
Roots of intersection satisfy $x_A + x_B = 2x_1$.
Using theory of equations on the intersection quadratic leads to the concise form $T = S_1$.
For Parabola: $yy_1 - 2a(x+x_1) = y_1^2 - 4ax_1$.

related_concepts.name: Diameter
related_concepts.definition: Locus of midpoints of a system of parallel chords.

subject: Math
title: Parametric Tangent (Ellipse)
description: Tangent at $(a \cos \theta, b \sin \theta)$.
derivation:
Using T=0 form $\frac{xx_1}{a^2} + \frac{yy_1}{b^2} = 1$.
Substitute $x_1 = a \cos \theta, y_1 = b \sin \theta$.
$\frac{x(a \cos \theta)}{a^2} + \frac{y(b \sin \theta)}{b^2} = 1$.
Simplify fractions to get the result.

related_concepts.name: Auxiliary Circle
related_concepts.definition: Points on auxiliary circle $(a \cos \theta, a \sin \theta)$ relate to ellipse points via $\theta$.

subject: Math
title: Normal to Ellipse
description: Equation of normal at $(a \cos \theta, b \sin \theta)$.
derivation:
Slope of tangent $m_T = -\frac{b \cos \theta}{a \sin \theta}$ (from implicit diff).
Slope of normal $m_N = \frac{a \sin \theta}{b \cos \theta}$.
Line: $y - b \sin \theta = \frac{a \sin \theta}{b \cos \theta} (x - a \cos \theta)$.
Multiply by $\frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta}$ and rearrange terms.
$x \frac{a}{\cos \theta} - y \frac{b}{\sin \theta} = a^2 - b^2$.

subject: Math
title: Director Circle (Hyperbola)
description: Locus of perpendicular tangents. Valid only if $a > b$.
derivation:
Similar to Ellipse derivation.
Tangents: $y - mx = \sqrt{a^2 m^2 - b^2}$.
Square and rearrange for quadratic in $m$.
Apply $m_1 m_2 = -1$.
Result: $x^2 + y^2 = a^2 - b^2$.
If $a < b$, $a^2 - b^2 < 0$, so no real circle exists (tangents cannot be perpendicular).

related_concepts.name: Rectangular Hyperbola
related_concepts.definition: If $a=b$, RHS is 0. Perpendicular tangents meet only at center (asymptotes).

subject: Math
title: Rectangular Hyperbola ($xy=c^2$)
description: Hyperbola rotated 45 degrees. Asymptotes are coordinate axes.
derivation:
Standard $x^2 - y^2 = a^2$ rotated by $45^\circ$.
Coordinate transform: $X = \frac{x+y}{\sqrt{2}}, Y = \frac{x-y}{\sqrt{2}}$.
$(X)^2 - (Y)^2 = a^2 \implies 2xy = a^2$.
Set $c^2 = a^2/2$.
Result: $xy = c^2$.

related_concepts.name: Parametric Point
related_concepts.definition: For $xy=c^2$, points are $(ct, c/t)$.

subject: Math
title: Tangent to Rect Hyperbola
description: Tangent at point $(ct, c/t)$ on $xy=c^2$.
derivation:
Point $P(ct, c/t)$.
Differentiate $xy=c^2 \implies y + xy' = 0 \implies y' = -y/x$.
Slope $m = - (c/t) / (ct) = -1/t^2$.
Line: $y - c/t = (-1/t^2)(x - ct)$.
$t^2y - ct = -x + ct \implies x + t^2y = 2ct$.
Divide by $t$: $x/t + ty = 2c$.

related_concepts.name: Implicit Differentiation
related_concepts.definition: Finding dy/dx without solving for y explicitly.

subject: Math
title: Normal to Rect Hyperbola
description: Normal at point $(ct, c/t)$ on $xy=c^2$.
derivation:
Tangent slope $m_T = -1/t^2$.
Normal slope $m_N = -1/m_T = t^2$.
Line: $y - c/t = t^2(x - ct)$.
$yt - c = t^3(x - ct) = xt^3 - ct^4$.
$xt^3 - yt - ct^4 + c = 0$.

related_concepts.name: Fourth Degree
related_concepts.definition: Equation is degree 4 in $t$, implying up to 4 normals can be drawn from a point.

subject: Math
title: Volume of Tetrahedron
description: Volume using coterminous edge vectors $\vec{a}, \vec{b}, \vec{c}$.
derivation:
Tetrahedron is a pyramid with triangular base.
Volume = $1/3 \times \text{Base Area} \times \text{Height}$.
Base Area = $1/2 |\vec{b} \times \vec{c}|$.
Height = Projection of $\vec{a}$ on normal.
$V = \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{2} |(\vec{b} \times \vec{c}) \cdot \vec{a}| = \frac{1}{6} [\vec{a} \vec{b} \vec{c}]$.

related_concepts.name: Scalar Triple Product
related_concepts.definition: Geometric representation of volume of parallelepiped (which is 6x tetrahedron vol).

subject: Math
title: Vector Triple Product Expansion
description: Formula for expanding VTP. Vector lies in plane of $\vec{b}$ and $\vec{c}$.
derivation:
Geometric Proof:
Let $\hat{i}$ be along $\vec{b}$, $\hat{j}$ in plane of $\vec{b}, \vec{c}$.
Calculate LHS and RHS components.
The result consistently follows the 'middle vector' rule.
Memory Aid: $\textbf{bac} - \textbf{cab}$ rule (dot product with outer vectors).

related_concepts.name: Orthogonality
related_concepts.definition: The result is perpendicular to $\vec{a}$.

subject: Math
title: Lagrange's Identity
description: Connection between dot and cross products magnitudes.
derivation:
$|\vec{a} \times \vec{b}|^2 = (ab \sin \theta)^2 = a^2 b^2 \sin^2 \theta$.
$(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b})^2 = (ab \cos \theta)^2 = a^2 b^2 \cos^2 \theta$.
Sum $= a^2 b^2 (\sin^2 \theta + \cos^2 \theta) = a^2 b^2 = |\vec{a}|^2 |\vec{b}|^2$.

related_concepts.name: Cauchy-Schwarz Inequality
related_concepts.definition: $(\vec{a} \cdot \vec{b})^2 \le |\vec{a}|^2 |\vec{b}|^2$ (Since cross product squared is non-negative).

subject: Math
title: Reciprocal System of Vectors
description: Set of vectors $\vec{a}', \vec{b}', \vec{c}'$ satisfying $\vec{a} \cdot \vec{a}' = 1$.
derivation:
Definition: $\vec{a}'$ must be perpendicular to $\vec{b}$ and $\vec{c}$, so along $\vec{b} \times \vec{c}$.
Let $\vec{a}' = k (\vec{b} \times \vec{c})$.
Condition: $\vec{a} \cdot \vec{a}' = 1 \implies k \vec{a} \cdot (\vec{b} \times \vec{c}) = 1$.
$k [\vec{a} \vec{b} \vec{c}] = 1 \implies k = 1/[\vec{a} \vec{b} \vec{c}]$.

related_concepts.name: Dual Basis
related_concepts.definition: Concept in linear algebra where basis vectors satisfy orthonormality conditions.

subject: Math
title: Image of Point in Plane
description: Coordinates $(x,y,z)$ of the reflection of $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$ in plane $ax+by+cz+d=0$.
derivation:
Let Image be $Q(x,y,z)$. Midpoint $M$ of $PQ$ lies on the plane.
Line $PQ$ is along normal $(a,b,c)$.
1. $\frac{x-x_1}{a} = \lambda \implies x = x_1 + a\lambda$.
2. Midpoint $M(x_1+a\lambda/2, ...)$ satisfies plane eq.
3. Solving for $\lambda$ gives $-2 \frac{P(x_1)}{a^2+b^2+c^2}$.
Substitute $\lambda$ back.

related_concepts.name: Reflection
related_concepts.definition: Geometric transformation mapping a point to its symmetric counterpart.

subject: Math
title: Foot of Perpendicular
description: Coordinates of the point on the plane closest to external point.
derivation:
Same logic as Image, but the point $(x,y,z)$ IS the point on the plane, not the reflection.
So, we don't need the midpoint logic.
The distance traveled along normal is just enough to reach the plane.
Factor is $-1$ instead of $-2$.

related_concepts.name: Projection
related_concepts.definition: The foot of the perpendicular is the orthogonal projection of the point onto the plane.

subject: Math
title: Shortest Distance (Skew Lines)
description: Scalar projection of the connector vector onto the common normal.
derivation:
Common Normal vector $\vec{n} = \vec{b}_1 \times \vec{b}_2$.
This vector is perpendicular to both lines.
Project the vector joining any two points on the lines ($\vec{AB} = \vec{a}_2 - \vec{a}_1$) onto $\vec{n}$.
Projection formula: $\frac{\vec{AB} \cdot \vec{n}}{|\vec{n}|}$.

related_concepts.name: Box Product
related_concepts.definition: Numerator can be written as $[(\vec{a}_2-\vec{a}_1) \; \vec{b}_1 \; \vec{b}_2]$.

subject: Math
title: Distance Between Parallel Planes
description: Distance between $ax+by+cz+d_1=0$ and $ax+by+cz+d_2=0$.
derivation:
Pick any point on Plane 1, say $(0, 0, -d_1/c)$ (assuming $c \neq 0$).
Find distance of this point from Plane 2 using point-plane distance formula.
Distance = $\frac{|a(0) + b(0) + c(-d_1/c) + d_2|}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}} = \frac{|-d_1 + d_2|}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2+c^2}}$.

related_concepts.name: Normalization
related_concepts.definition: Making the coefficients of x, y, z identical before applying the formula.

subject: Math
title: Angle Between Line and Plane
description: Angle $\theta$ is between line and its projection. Complementary to angle with normal.
derivation:
Let $\alpha$ be angle between Line vector $\vec{b}$ and Plane Normal $\vec{n}$.
$\cos \alpha = \frac{\vec{b} \cdot \vec{n}}{|b||n|}$.
The angle with the plane $\theta = 90^\circ - \alpha$.
$\sin \theta = \sin(90-\alpha) = \cos \alpha$.
Thus $\sin \theta$ uses the dot product formula.

related_concepts.name: Complementary Angle
related_concepts.definition: The shift from cosine to sine accounts for the normal being $90^\circ$ to surface.

subject: Math
title: Family of Planes
description: Equation representing all planes passing through the intersection line of $P_1=0$ and $P_2=0$.
derivation:
Let intersection line be $L$. For any point on $L$, $P_1=0$ and $P_2=0$.
Thus $P_1 + \lambda P_2 = 0$ is satisfied.
Since the equation is linear in x, y, z, it represents a plane.
$\lambda$ is determined by an extra condition (e.g., passing through a point).

related_concepts.name: Linear Combination
related_concepts.definition: Constructing new solutions from existing ones.

subject: Math
title: Coplanarity of Lines
description: Condition for two lines to intersect or be parallel (lie in same plane).
derivation:
If lines are coplanar, the shortest distance between them is zero.
Using SD formula: Numerator must be zero.
The vector joining fixed points $(\vec{a}_2 - \vec{a}_1)$ must be perpendicular to the common normal $\vec{b}_1 \times \vec{b}_2$.
This implies the three vectors are coplanar (Scalar Triple Product = 0).

related_concepts.name: Determinant Form
related_concepts.definition: $\begin{vmatrix} x_2-x_1 & y_2-y_1 & z_2-z_1 \\ a_1 & b_1 & c_1 \\ a_2 & b_2 & c_2 \end{vmatrix} = 0$.

subject: Math
title: Power Set Cardinality
description: Total number of subsets of a set A with n elements.
derivation:
Let set A have $n$ elements.
To form a subset, for each element $x \in A$, there are exactly 2 choices:
1. Include $x$ in the subset.
2. Exclude $x$ from the subset.
Total combinations = $2 \times 2 \times \dots \times 2$ ($n$ times) = $2^n$.

related_concepts.name: Binomial Theorem
related_concepts.definition: $\sum_{r=0}^n \binom{n}{r} = 2^n$ (Sum of all possible selections).

subject: Math
title: Cartesian Product Cardinality
description: Total number of ordered pairs $(a, b)$ where $a \in A, b \in B$.
derivation:
Let $n(A) = p$ and $n(B) = q$.
For each of the $p$ elements in A, we can pair it with any of the $q$ elements in B.
This forms $p$ groups of $q$ pairs.
Total pairs = $p + p + \dots$ ($q$ times? No, $p$ times $q$) = $p \times q$.

related_concepts.name: Ordered Pair
related_concepts.definition: A pair $(a, b)$ where order matters; $(a, b) \neq (b, a)$ unless $a=b$.

subject: Math
title: Total Number of Relations
description: Number of possible relations from set A ($m$ elements) to set B ($n$ elements).
derivation:
A relation is a subset of the Cartesian product $A \times B$.
Number of elements in $A \times B$ is $mn$.
The number of subsets of a set with $k$ elements is $2^k$.
Substituting $k = mn$, Total Relations = $2^{mn}$.

related_concepts.name: Empty Relation
related_concepts.definition: The relation containing no ordered pairs (subset $\phi$).

subject: Math
title: Number of Reflexive Relations
description: Relations on set A where every element is related to itself.
derivation:
Total pairs in $A \times A$ is $n^2$.
Diagonal pairs $(a,a)$ are $n$. Non-diagonal pairs are $n^2 - n$.
For reflexivity, all $n$ diagonal pairs MUST be included (1 choice each).
The remaining $n^2 - n$ pairs can be either included or excluded (2 choices each).
Total = $1^n \times 2^{n^2-n} = 2^{n(n-1)}$.

related_concepts.name: Identity Relation
related_concepts.definition: Relation containing ONLY the diagonal pairs $\{(a,a) \forall a \in A\}$.

subject: Math
title: Number of Symmetric Relations
description: Relations where $(a,b) \in R \implies (b,a) \in R$.
derivation:
Pairs in $A \times A$ can be grouped:
1. Diagonal elements $(a,a)$: $n$ pairs. Each has 2 choices (in/out).
2. Off-diagonal pairs $\{(a,b), (b,a)\}$: $(n^2-n)/2$ sets. For symmetry, they must be selected together (either both in or both out).
Total choices = $2^n \times 2^{(n^2-n)/2} = 2^{(2n + n^2 - n)/2} = 2^{n(n+1)/2}$.

related_concepts.name: Upper Triangular Matrix
related_concepts.definition: Analogy to determining independent entries in a symmetric matrix.

subject: Math
title: Number of One-One Functions
description: Injective maps from set A ($m$ elements) to set B ($n$ elements). Valid if $n \ge m$.
derivation:
Let elements of A be $a_1, a_2, \dots, a_m$.
$a_1$ has $n$ choices in B.
$a_2$ has $n-1$ choices (cannot match $a_1$'s image).
$a_3$ has $n-2$ choices.
...
$a_m$ has $n-(m-1)$ choices.
Total = $n(n-1)\dots(n-m+1) = ^nP_m$.

related_concepts.name: Pigeonhole Principle
related_concepts.definition: If $m > n$, at least one element in B must be mapped to twice, so 0 one-one functions.

subject: Math
title: Number of Onto Functions
description: Surjective maps from A ($m$) to B ($n$). Requires $m \ge n$.
derivation:
Total functions = $n^m$.
Subtract functions that miss at least 1 element of B: $\binom{n}{1}(n-1)^m$.
Add back functions missing at least 2 (double counted): $\binom{n}{2}(n-2)^m$.
Using Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion:
$N = n^m - \binom{n}{1}(n-1)^m + \binom{n}{2}(n-2)^m - \dots$

related_concepts.name: Stirling Numbers
related_concepts.definition: Related to partitioning set A into n non-empty subsets ($S(m,n) \times n!$).

subject: Math
title: Number of Bijections
description: One-one and Onto functions. Possible only if $n(A) = n(B) = n$.
derivation:
From A ($n$) to B ($n$).
For One-One: $^nP_n = n!$.
For Onto: Using formula with $m=n$: $n^n - \binom{n}{1}(n-1)^n \dots = n!$.
Simplest logic: First element has $n$ choices, second $n-1$, ..., last 1.
$n \times (n-1) \times \dots \times 1 = n!$.

related_concepts.name: Permutation
related_concepts.definition: A bijection from a set to itself is a permutation.

subject: Math
title: Base Change Formula
description: Formula to convert logarithm to a new base $c$.
derivation:
Let $x = \log_a b \implies a^x = b$.
Take $\log_c$ on both sides:
$\log_c (a^x) = \log_c b$
$x \log_c a = \log_c b$
$x = \frac{\log_c b}{\log_c a}$.

related_concepts.name: Reciprocal Property
related_concepts.definition: $\log_a b = \frac{1}{\log_b a}$ (Setting $c=b$).

subject: Math
title: Base Power Rule
description: The exponent of the base comes out as a reciprocal fraction.
derivation:
Let $x = \log_{a^k} b \implies (a^k)^x = b$.
$a^{kx} = b$.
Convert to log base $a$:
$\log_a (a^{kx}) = \log_a b$.
$kx = \log_a b \implies x = \frac{1}{k} \log_a b$.

related_concepts.name: Argument Power Rule
related_concepts.definition: $\log_a (b^k) = k \log_a b$.

subject: Math
title: Fundamental Log Identity
description: Exponential and Logarithmic functions are inverses.
derivation:
Let $y = \log_a x$.
By definition of logarithm: $a^y = x$.
Substitute $y$ back into the exponent:
$a^{\log_a x} = x$.

subject: Math
title: Log Exchange Property
description: Base and argument can be swapped.
derivation:
Take $\log_c$ of LHS: $\log_c (a^{\log_c b}) = (\log_c b)(\log_c a)$.
Take $\log_c$ of RHS: $\log_c (b^{\log_c a}) = (\log_c a)(\log_c b)$.
Since the logs are equal (multiplication is commutative), the original values are equal.

related_concepts.name: Commutativity
related_concepts.definition: $xy = yx$.

subject: Math
title: Modulus Inequality (<)
description: Solution set for absolute value less than a positive constant.
derivation:
Case 1 ($x \ge 0$): $|x| = x$. So $x < a$. Combine: $0 \le x < a$.
Case 2 ($x < 0$): $|x| = -x$. So $-x < a \implies x > -a$. Combine: $-a < x < 0$.
Union of cases: $-a < x < a$.

related_concepts.name: Distance Interpretation
related_concepts.definition: Distance of x from 0 is less than a.

subject: Math
title: Triangle Inequality
description: Fundamental inequality in analysis.
derivation:
Square both sides (since both $\ge 0$):
LHS$^2 = |a+b|^2 = (a+b)^2 = a^2 + b^2 + 2ab$.
RHS$^2 = (|a|+|b|)^2 = |a|^2 + |b|^2 + 2|a||b| = a^2 + b^2 + 2|ab|$.
Since $x \le |x|$, we have $ab \le |ab|$.
Thus LHS$^2 \le$ RHS$^2 \implies |a+b| \le |a|+|b|$.

related_concepts.name: Equality Condition
related_concepts.definition: Equality holds if $a$ and $b$ have the same sign ($ab \ge 0$).

subject: Math
title: Conjunction (AND)
description: True only if both statements p and q are true.
derivation:
Truth Table Definition:
| p | q | p^q |
| T | T |  T  |
| T | F |  F  |
| F | T |  F  |
| F | F |  F  |

related_concepts.name: Intersection
related_concepts.definition: Analogous to set intersection ($A \cap B$).

subject: Math
title: Implication Equivalence
description: Equivalent form of conditional statement without arrow.
derivation:
Analyze Truth Values:
$p \rightarrow q$ is False ONLY when $p=T, q=F$.
$\sim p \lor q$ is False ONLY when $\sim p=F$ (so $p=T$) AND $q=F$.
Since the 'False' condition is identical, the statements are logically equivalent.

related_concepts.name: Conditional Statement
related_concepts.definition: If p then q.

subject: Math
title: Negation of Implication
description: Used to disprove implications (Counter-example method).
derivation:
Using equivalence $p \rightarrow q \equiv \sim p \lor q$.
$\sim(p \rightarrow q) \equiv \sim(\sim p \lor q)$.
Apply De Morgan's Law:
$\equiv \sim(\sim p) \land \sim q$
$\equiv p \land \sim q$.

related_concepts.name: Counter Example
related_concepts.definition: A case where hypothesis p is true but conclusion q is false.

subject: Math
title: Equation of Asymptotes
description: Pair of lines passing through origin that the hyperbola never touches.
derivation:
Hyperbola: $\frac{x^2}{a^2} - \frac{y^2}{b^2} = 1$.
As $x \to \infty$, the 1 becomes negligible.
$\frac{x^2}{a^2} - \frac{y^2}{b^2} \approx 0$.
Factorize: $(\frac{x}{a} - \frac{y}{b})(\frac{x}{a} + \frac{y}{b}) = 0$.
These linear factors represent the asymptotes.

subject: Math
title: Angle Between Asymptotes
description: Total angle containing the hyperbola.
derivation:
Slope of asymptote $y = \frac{b}{a}x$ is $m = b/a$.
Angle with x-axis $\theta = \tan^{-1}(b/a)$.
By symmetry, the other asymptote is at $-\theta$.
Total angle between them is $\theta - (-\theta) = 2\theta = 2 \tan^{-1}(b/a)$.

related_concepts.name: Rectangular Hyperbola
related_concepts.definition: If $b=a$, angle is $2 \tan^{-1}(1) = 90^\circ$.

subject: Math
title: Hyperbola-Conjugate Relation
description: Relation between equations of Hyperbola (H), Conjugate (C), and Asymptotes (A).
derivation:
Let $S = \frac{x^2}{a^2} - \frac{y^2}{b^2}$.
Equation of H: $S - 1 = 0$.
Equation of Asymptotes A: $S = 0$.
Equation of Conjugate C: $S + 1 = 0$ (axis signs flipped).
Check: $H + C = (S-1) + (S+1) = 2S = 2A$.

related_concepts.name: Constant Difference
related_concepts.definition: Any line parallel to an asymptote cuts H and C at points equidistant from the asymptote.

subject: Math
title: Rectangular Hyperbola (Parametric)
description: Parametric form for $xy = c^2$.
derivation:
Equation: $xy = c^2$.
Let $x = ct$. Substitute into eq:
$(ct)y = c^2 \implies y = c/t$.
This satisfies the equation for all $t \neq 0$.
Commonly used for finding tangents and normals.

related_concepts.name: Standard Parameter
related_concepts.definition: $x = a \sec \theta, y = b \tan \theta$ for $x^2/a^2 - y^2/b^2 = 1$.

subject: Math
title: Coefficient of Variation (CV)
description: Dimensionless measure of relative variability/dispersion.
derivation:
Standard Deviation ($\sigma$) has units of the data.
Mean ($\bar{x}$) has units of the data.
Ratio $\sigma/\bar{x}$ cancels units.
Multiply by 100 to express as percentage.
Used to compare consistency of two datasets with different units/means.

related_concepts.name: Consistency
related_concepts.definition: Lower CV implies higher consistency (less fluctuation relative to mean).

subject: Math
title: Combined Mean
description: Weighted average of two distinct groups of data.
derivation:
Definition of Mean: $\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x}{n} \implies \sum x = n \bar{x}$.
Sum of Group 1: $S_1 = n_1 \bar{x}_1$.
Sum of Group 2: $S_2 = n_2 \bar{x}_2$.
Total Sum: $S_{total} = n_1 \bar{x}_1 + n_2 \bar{x}_2$.
Total Count: $N = n_1 + n_2$.
Combined Mean = $S_{total} / N$.

related_concepts.name: Weighted Mean
related_concepts.definition: General form where weights $w_i$ are assigned to values $x_i$.

subject: Math
title: Combined Variance
description: Variance of merged dataset. $d_1 = \bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_{comb}$, $d_2 = \bar{x}_2 - \bar{x}_{comb}$.
derivation:
Variance definition: $\sigma^2 = \frac{\sum x^2}{n} - (\bar{x})^2 \implies \sum x^2 = n(\sigma^2 + \bar{x}^2)$.
Calculate $\sum x^2$ for both groups and add them to get Total Sum Squares.
$\sum x_{comb}^2 = n_1(\sigma_1^2 + \bar{x}_1^2) + n_2(\sigma_2^2 + \bar{x}_2^2)$.
New Variance = $\frac{\sum x_{comb}^2}{N} - (\bar{x}_{comb})^2$.
Simplifying this expression yields the formula involving deviation $d$.

related_concepts.name: Analysis of Variance
related_concepts.definition: Statistical method to analyze differences among group means.

subject: Math
title: Corner Point Theorem
description: The optimal value (max/min) of a linear objective function $Z = ax + by$ always occurs at a corner point of the feasible region.
derivation:
The feasible region is a convex polygon.
The objective function $Z = ax + by = c$ represents a family of parallel lines.
As we increase/decrease $c$, the line moves parallel to itself.
The maximum or minimum value is reached when the line just touches the last point of the region before leaving it.
This point is geometrically guaranteed to be a vertex (or an edge connecting two vertices).

related_concepts.name: Feasible Region
related_concepts.definition: The set of all points satisfying the system of linear inequalities.

subject: Math
title: Locus: Perpendicular Bisector
description: Locus of point $P(\vec{r})$ equidistant from $A(\vec{a})$ and $B(\vec{b})$ is the perpendicular bisector plane.
derivation:
Start with $|\vec{r} - \vec{a}|^2 = |\vec{r} - \vec{b}|^2$.
$(\vec{r}-\vec{a}) \cdot (\vec{r}-\vec{a}) = (\vec{r}-\vec{b}) \cdot (\vec{r}-\vec{b})$.
$r^2 - 2\vec{r}\cdot\vec{a} + a^2 = r^2 - 2\vec{r}\cdot\vec{b} + b^2$.
$2\vec{r} \cdot (\vec{a} - \vec{b}) = a^2 - b^2 = (\vec{a}-\vec{b}) \cdot (\vec{a}+\vec{b})$.
$\vec{r} \cdot (\vec{a}-\vec{b}) = \frac{\vec{a}+\vec{b}}{2} \cdot (\vec{a}-\vec{b})$.
This is the plane passing through midpoint with normal $(\vec{a}-\vec{b})$.

related_concepts.name: Midpoint
related_concepts.definition: Position vector $(\vec{a}+\vec{b})/2$.

subject: Math
title: Locus: Plane Through Origin
description: Locus of points perpendicular to a fixed vector $\vec{a}$.
derivation:
Let $P(\vec{r})$ be any point on the locus.
The condition states that the position vector $\vec{r}$ (from origin to P) is perpendicular to the fixed vector $\vec{a}$.
Dot Product Condition: $\vec{r} \cdot \vec{a} = |r||a| \cos(90^\circ) = 0$.
Geometrically, this generates a plane passing through the origin with normal $\vec{a}$.

related_concepts.name: Normal Form
related_concepts.definition: $\vec{r} \cdot \hat{n} = 0$.

subject: Math
title: Sphere Equation (Diametric Form)
description: Locus of point $P(\vec{r})$ forming a right angle with diameter endpoints $A(\vec{a})$ and $B(\vec{b})$.
derivation:
Properties of a sphere: Angle in a semi-circle is $90^\circ$.
Vector $\vec{AP} = \vec{r} - \vec{a}$.
Vector $\vec{BP} = \vec{r} - \vec{b}$.
Condition: $\vec{AP} \perp \vec{BP}$.
Dot product: $\vec{AP} \cdot \vec{BP} = 0 \implies (\vec{r} - \vec{a}) \cdot (\vec{r} - \vec{b}) = 0$.

related_concepts.name: Thales's Theorem
related_concepts.definition: If A, B, and C are points on a circle where the line AC is a diameter, then the angle ABC is a right angle.

subject: Math
title: Equation of Bisector Planes
visual_data: \frac{a_1 x + ... + d_1}{\sqrt{\sum a_1^2}} = \pm \frac{a_2 x + ... + d_2}{\sqrt{\sum a_2^2}}
description: Locus of points equidistant from two intersecting planes.
derivation:
Let $P(x,y,z)$ be a point on the bisector.
Perpendicular distance to Plane 1 = Perpendicular distance to Plane 2.
$d_1 = d_2$.
$\frac{|a_1 x + b_1 y + c_1 z + d_1|}{\sqrt{a_1^2+b_1^2+c_1^2}} = \frac{|a_2 x + b_2 y + c_2 z + d_2|}{\sqrt{a_2^2+b_2^2+c_2^2}}$.
Removing modulus gives $\pm$ sign, yielding two bisector planes (Acute and Obtuse).

related_concepts.name: Acute Angle Bisector
related_concepts.definition: Determined by checking the angle between the bisector normal and plane normal.

subject: Math
title: Condition for Line in Plane
description: Line $\vec{r} = \vec{a} + \lambda \vec{b}$ lies in plane $\vec{r} \cdot \vec{n} = d$.
derivation:
Two conditions must be met:
1. Parallelism: The line must be perpendicular to the plane's normal.
   $\vec{b} \cdot \vec{n} = 0$ ($al + bm + cn = 0$ in Cartesian).
2. Incidence: At least one point on the line (e.g., $\vec{a}$) must lie on the plane.
   $\vec{a} \cdot \vec{n} = d$ ($ax_1 + by_1 + cz_1 + d = 0$).

related_concepts.name: Coplanarity
related_concepts.definition: State of geometric objects lying in the same plane.

subject: Math
title: Homogeneous Equation
description: Represents a pair of straight lines passing through the origin.
derivation:
Let the two lines be $y - m_1x = 0$ and $y - m_2x = 0$.
Combined equation: $(y - m_1x)(y - m_2x) = 0$.
$y^2 - (m_1+m_2)xy + m_1m_2x^2 = 0$.
Compare with standard form divided by $b$:
$(a/b)x^2 + (2h/b)xy + y^2 = 0$.
Coefficients match: $m_1+m_2 = -2h/b$ and $m_1m_2 = a/b$.

related_concepts.name: Homogeneous Function
related_concepts.definition: A function where $f(tx, ty) = t^n f(x,y)$. Here degree n=2.

subject: Math
title: Angle Between Pair of Lines
description: Angle between the lines represented by $ax^2 + 2hxy + by^2 = 0$.
derivation:
From line theory: $\tan \theta = \left| \frac{m_1 - m_2}{1 + m_1 m_2} \right|$.
Use algebraic identity: $(m_1 - m_2)^2 = (m_1+m_2)^2 - 4m_1m_2$.
Substitute sums/products: $(-2h/b)^2 - 4(a/b) = \frac{4h^2 - 4ab}{b^2}$.
$\sqrt{(m_1-m_2)^2} = \frac{2\sqrt{h^2-ab}}{b}$.
Denominator $1 + m_1 m_2 = 1 + a/b = (a+b)/b$.
Result follows.

related_concepts.name: Perpendicularity
related_concepts.definition: $a+b=0$ (Sum of coeffs of $x^2$ and $y^2$ is zero).

subject: Math
title: Equation of Angle Bisectors
description: Combined equation of the pair of lines bisecting the angles between $ax^2+2hxy+by^2=0$.
derivation:
Let the lines be inclined at $\theta_1$ and $\theta_2$.
Bisector angles are $\frac{\theta_1+\theta_2}{2}$ and $\frac{\theta_1+\theta_2}{2} + 90^\circ$.
Locus of point $P(x,y)$ (polar $r, \theta$) such that $2\theta = \theta_1+\theta_2$ or $2\theta = \theta_1+\theta_2 + 180$.
$\tan 2\theta = \tan(\theta_1+\theta_2) = \frac{m_1+m_2}{1-m_1m_2}$.
$\frac{2 \tan \theta}{1 - \tan^2 \theta} = \frac{-2h/b}{1-a/b}$.
Substitute $\tan \theta = y/x$: $\frac{2(y/x)}{1-(y/x)^2} = \frac{-2h}{b-a}$.
Simplifies to standard form.

related_concepts.name: Perpendicular Bisectors
related_concepts.definition: The angle bisectors of a pair of lines are always perpendicular to each other.

subject: Math
title: Condition for General Equation
description: Condition for $ax^2 + 2hxy + by^2 + 2gx + 2fy + c = 0$ to represent a pair of lines.
derivation:
The general equation represents a pair of lines if the discriminant $\Delta$ of the conic is zero.
Determinant form:
$\Delta = \begin{vmatrix} a & h & g \\ h & b & f \\ g & f & c \end{vmatrix} = 0$.
Expansion of this determinant yields the standard condition equation.

related_concepts.name: Point of Intersection
related_concepts.definition: Found by partial differentiation: $\frac{\partial S}{\partial x} = 0, \frac{\partial S}{\partial y} = 0$.

subject: Math
title: Section Formula (Complex)
description: Complex coordinate of point dividing segment $z_1z_2$ in ratio $m:n$.
derivation:
Identical to vector section formula.
Let $z_1$ and $z_2$ be position vectors.
Vector $\vec{P} = \frac{m\vec{B} + n\vec{A}}{m+n}$.
Since complex numbers behave like 2D vectors for addition/scaling:
$z = \frac{mz_2 + nz_1}{m+n}$.
For external division, replace $n$ with $-n$.

subject: Math
title: Equation of Line (Complex)
description: General equation of a line where $a \in \mathbb{C}, b \in \mathbb{R}$.
derivation:
Cartesian line: $lx + my + n = 0$.
Substitute $x = (z+\bar{z})/2$ and $y = (z-\bar{z})/2i$.
$l(\frac{z+\bar{z}}{2}) + m(\frac{z-\bar{z}}{2i}) + n = 0$.
$z(l/2 + m/2i) + \bar{z}(l/2 - m/2i) + n = 0$.
Let $a = l/2 - mi/2$. Then coeff of $z$ is $\bar{a}$.
$\bar{a}z + a\bar{z} + n = 0$.

related_concepts.name: Hermitian Form
related_concepts.definition: The structure $\bar{a}z + a\bar{z}$ ensures the result is real.

subject: Math
title: Bernoulli's Equation
description: Non-linear ODE reducible to linear form.
derivation:
1. Divide by $y^n$: $y^{-n} y' + P y^{1-n} = Q$.
2. Substitution: Let $z = y^{1-n}$.
   Differentiation: $z' = (1-n) y^{-n} y'$.
3. Replace terms: $\frac{z'}{1-n} + Pz = Q$.
4. Standard Linear Form: $z' + (1-n)P z = (1-n)Q$. Solve using IF.

related_concepts.name: Reduction to Linear
related_concepts.definition: Method of transforming non-linear equations using substitution.

subject: Math
title: Newton's Law of Cooling
description: Rate of cooling is proportional to temperature difference with surroundings.
derivation:
Physical Law: Rate of heat loss $\propto \Delta T$.
$-\frac{dT}{dt} \propto (T - T_s)$.
$\frac{dT}{dt} = -k(T - T_s)$.
Separable form: $\frac{dT}{T-T_s} = -k dt$.
Solution: $\ln(T-T_s) = -kt + C \implies T(t) = T_s + C e^{-kt}$.

related_concepts.name: Exponential Decay
related_concepts.definition: Process where quantity decreases at a rate proportional to its current value.

subject: Math
title: Integration as Limit of Sum
description: Converting infinite series to definite integrals.
derivation:
Riemann Sum definition of integral.
Partition interval $[0, 1]$ into $n$ sub-intervals of width $\Delta x = 1/n$.
Points $x_r = r/n$.
Sum $S = \sum f(x_r) \Delta x = \sum f(r/n) (1/n)$.
As $n \to \infty$, the sum converges to the integral $\int_0^1 f(x) dx$.

related_concepts.name: Riemann Sum
related_concepts.definition: Approximation of area under curve using rectangles.

subject: Math
title: Wallis Formula
description: Reduction formula for powers of sine/cosine. $K=\pi/2$ if even, 1 if odd.
derivation:
Let $I_n = \int_0^{\pi/2} \sin^n x dx$.
By Integration by Parts (reduction): $I_n = \frac{n-1}{n} I_{n-2}$.
Recursive application:
$I_n = \frac{n-1}{n} \cdot \frac{n-3}{n-2} \cdot \dots \cdot I_0 \text{ or } I_1$.
$I_0 = \int 1 dx = \pi/2$. $I_1 = \int \sin x dx = 1$.

related_concepts.name: Double Factorial
related_concepts.definition: $n!!$ is product of integers with same parity as n down to 1 or 2.

subject: Math
title: Cayley-Hamilton Theorem
description: Every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic equation.
derivation:
Characteristic Equation: $det(A - \lambda I) = 0$.
This expands to a polynomial: $c_0 \lambda^n + c_1 \lambda^{n-1} + \dots + c_n = 0$.
The theorem states that substituting matrix $A$ for scalar $\lambda$ yields the zero matrix:
$c_0 A^n + c_1 A^{n-1} + \dots + c_n I = O$.
Used to find Inverse ($A^{-1}$) or higher powers ($A^k$).

related_concepts.name: Eigenvalues
related_concepts.definition: Roots of the characteristic equation.

subject: Math
title: Power Set Cardinality
description: Total number of subsets of a set A with n elements.
derivation:
Let set A have $n$ elements.
To form a subset, for each element $x \in A$, there are exactly 2 choices:
1. Include $x$ in the subset.
2. Exclude $x$ from the subset.
Total combinations = $2 \times 2 \times \dots \times 2$ ($n$ times) = $2^n$.

related_concepts.name: Binomial Theorem
related_concepts.definition: $\sum_{r=0}^n \binom{n}{r} = 2^n$ (Sum of all possible selections).

subject: Math
title: Cartesian Product Cardinality
description: Total number of ordered pairs $(a, b)$ where $a \in A, b \in B$.
derivation:
Let $n(A) = m$ and $n(B) = n$.
For each of the $m$ elements in A, we can pair it with any of the $n$ elements in B.
This forms $m$ groups of $n$ pairs.
Total pairs = $n + n + \dots$ ($m$ times) = $m \times n$.

related_concepts.name: Ordered Pair
related_concepts.definition: A pair $(a, b)$ where order matters; $(a, b) \neq (b, a)$ unless $a=b$.

subject: Math
title: Total Number of Relations
description: Number of possible relations from set A ($m$ elements) to set B ($n$ elements).
derivation:
A relation is defined as a subset of the Cartesian product $A \times B$.
Number of elements in $A \times B$ is $mn$.
The number of subsets of a set with $k$ elements is $2^k$.
Substituting $k = mn$, Total Relations = $2^{mn}$.

related_concepts.name: Empty Relation
related_concepts.definition: The relation containing no ordered pairs (subset $\phi$).

subject: Math
title: Number of Reflexive Relations
description: Relations on set A where every element is related to itself.
derivation:
Total pairs in $A \times A$ is $n^2$.
Diagonal pairs $(a,a)$ are $n$. Non-diagonal pairs are $n^2 - n$.
For reflexivity, all $n$ diagonal pairs MUST be included (1 choice each).
The remaining $n^2 - n$ pairs can be either included or excluded (2 choices each).
Total = $1^n \times 2^{n^2-n} = 2^{n(n-1)}$.

related_concepts.name: Identity Relation
related_concepts.definition: Relation containing ONLY the diagonal pairs $\{(a,a) \forall a \in A\}$.

subject: Math
title: Number of Symmetric Relations
description: Relations where $(a,b) \in R \implies (b,a) \in R$.
derivation:
Pairs in $A \times A$ can be grouped:
1. Diagonal elements $(a,a)$: $n$ pairs. Each has 2 choices (in/out).
2. Off-diagonal pairs $\{(a,b), (b,a)\}$: $(n^2-n)/2$ sets. For symmetry, they must be selected together (either both in or both out).
Total choices = $2^n \times 2^{(n^2-n)/2} = 2^{(2n + n^2 - n)/2} = 2^{n(n+1)/2}$.

related_concepts.name: Matrix Symmetry
related_concepts.definition: Equivalent to the number of possible symmetric $(0,1)$ matrices.

subject: Math
title: Number of One-One Functions
description: Injective maps from set A ($m$ elements) to set B ($n$ elements). Valid if $n \ge m$.
derivation:
Let elements of A be $a_1, a_2, \dots, a_m$.
$a_1$ has $n$ choices in B.
$a_2$ has $n-1$ choices (cannot match $a_1$'s image).
$a_3$ has $n-2$ choices.
...
$a_m$ has $n-(m-1)$ choices.
Total = $n(n-1)\dots(n-m+1) = ^nP_m$.

related_concepts.name: Pigeonhole Principle
related_concepts.definition: If $m > n$, at least one element in B must be mapped to twice, so 0 one-one functions.

subject: Math
title: Number of Onto Functions
description: Surjective maps from A ($m$) to B ($n$). Requires $m \ge n$.
derivation:
Total functions = $n^m$.
Subtract functions that miss at least 1 element of B: $\binom{n}{1}(n-1)^m$.
Add back functions missing at least 2 (double counted): $\binom{n}{2}(n-2)^m$.
Using Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion:
$N = n^m - \binom{n}{1}(n-1)^m + \binom{n}{2}(n-2)^m - \dots$

related_concepts.name: Stirling Numbers
related_concepts.definition: Related to partitioning set A into n non-empty subsets ($S(m,n) \times n!$).

subject: Math
title: Number of Bijections
description: One-one and Onto functions. Possible only if $n(A) = n(B) = n$.
derivation:
From A ($n$) to B ($n$).
For One-One: $^nP_n = n!$.
For Onto: Using formula with $m=n$: $n^n - \binom{n}{1}(n-1)^n \dots = n!$.
Simplest logic: First element has $n$ choices, second $n-1$, ..., last 1.
$n \times (n-1) \times \dots \times 1 = n!$.

related_concepts.name: Permutation
related_concepts.definition: A bijection from a set to itself is a permutation.

subject: Math
title: Base Change Formula
description: Formula to convert logarithm to a new base $c$.
derivation:
Let $x = \log_a b \implies a^x = b$.
Take $\log_c$ on both sides:
$\log_c (a^x) = \log_c b$
$x \log_c a = \log_c b$
$x = \frac{\log_c b}{\log_c a}$.

related_concepts.name: Reciprocal Property
related_concepts.definition: $\log_a b = \frac{1}{\log_b a}$ (Setting $c=b$).

subject: Math
title: Base Power Rule
description: The exponent of the base comes out as a reciprocal fraction.
derivation:
Let $x = \log_{a^k} b \implies (a^k)^x = b$.
$a^{kx} = b$.
Convert to log base $a$:
$\log_a (a^{kx}) = \log_a b$.
$kx = \log_a b \implies x = \frac{1}{k} \log_a b$.

related_concepts.name: Argument Power Rule
related_concepts.definition: $\log_a (b^k) = k \log_a b$.

subject: Math
title: Fundamental Log Identity
description: Exponential and Logarithmic functions are inverses.
derivation:
Let $y = \log_a x$.
By definition of logarithm: $a^y = x$.
Substitute $y$ back into the exponent:
$a^{\log_a x} = x$.

subject: Math
title: Log Exchange Property
description: Base and argument can be swapped.
derivation:
Take $\log_c$ of LHS: $\log_c (a^{\log_c b}) = (\log_c b)(\log_c a)$.
Take $\log_c$ of RHS: $\log_c (b^{\log_c a}) = (\log_c a)(\log_c b)$.
Since the logs are equal (multiplication is commutative), the original values are equal.

related_concepts.name: Commutativity
related_concepts.definition: $xy = yx$.

subject: Math
title: Modulus Inequality (<)
description: Solution set for absolute value less than a positive constant.
derivation:
Case 1 ($x \ge 0$): $|x| = x$. So $x < a$. Combine: $0 \le x < a$.
Case 2 ($x < 0$): $|x| = -x$. So $-x < a \implies x > -a$. Combine: $-a < x < 0$.
Union of cases: $-a < x < a$.

related_concepts.name: Distance Interpretation
related_concepts.definition: Distance of x from 0 is less than a.

subject: Math
title: Modulus Inequality (>)
description: Solution set for absolute value greater than a positive constant.
derivation:
Case 1 ($x \ge 0$): $|x| = x$. So $x > a$.
Case 2 ($x < 0$): $|x| = -x$. So $-x > a \implies x < -a$.
Union of cases: $x \in (-\infty, -a) \cup (a, \infty)$.

related_concepts.name: Exterior Region
related_concepts.definition: Points strictly outside the interval $[-a, a]$.

subject: Math
title: Triangle Inequality
description: Fundamental inequality in analysis.
derivation:
Square both sides (since both $\ge 0$):
LHS$^2 = |a+b|^2 = (a+b)^2 = a^2 + b^2 + 2ab$.
RHS$^2 = (|a|+|b|)^2 = |a|^2 + |b|^2 + 2|a||b| = a^2 + b^2 + 2|ab|$.
Since $x \le |x|$, we have $ab \le |ab|$.
Thus LHS$^2 \le$ RHS$^2 \implies |a+b| \le |a|+|b|$.

related_concepts.name: Equality Condition
related_concepts.definition: Equality holds if $a$ and $b$ have the same sign ($ab \ge 0$).

subject: Math
title: Reverse Triangle Inequality
description: Lower bound for the absolute difference.
derivation:
Write $a = (a-b) + b$.
Using Triangle Inequality: $|a| = |(a-b) + b| \le |a-b| + |b|$.
Rearrange: $|a| - |b| \le |a-b|$.
Similarly, starting with $b = (b-a) + a$, we get $|b| - |a| \le |b-a| = |a-b|$.
Combining both gives $||a| - |b|| \le |a-b|$.

related_concepts.name: Metric Space
related_concepts.definition: A fundamental property required for any distance function $d(x,y)$.

subject: Math
title: Conjunction (AND)
description: True only if both statements p and q are true.
derivation:
Truth Table Definition:
| p | q | p $\land$ q |
| T | T |  T  |
| T | F |  F  |
| F | T |  F  |
| F | F |  F  |

related_concepts.name: Intersection
related_concepts.definition: Analogous to set intersection ($A \cap B$).

subject: Math
title: Disjunction (OR)
description: True if at least one of the statements p or q is true.
derivation:
Truth Table Definition:
| p | q | p $\lor$ q |
| T | T |  T  |
| T | F |  T  |
| F | T |  T  |
| F | F |  F  |
Note: This is 'inclusive OR'.

related_concepts.name: Union
related_concepts.definition: Analogous to set union ($A \cup B$).

subject: Math
title: Implication Equivalence
description: Equivalent form of conditional statement without arrow.
derivation:
Analyze Truth Values:
$p \rightarrow q$ is False ONLY when $p=T, q=F$.
$\sim p \lor q$ is False ONLY when $\sim p=F$ (so $p=T$) AND $q=F$.
Since the 'False' condition is identical, the statements are logically equivalent.

related_concepts.name: Conditional Statement
related_concepts.definition: If p then q.

subject: Math
title: Biconditional (IFF)
description: True if p and q have the same truth value.
derivation:
Combines forward and backward implication.
Truth Table:
| p | q | p $\leftrightarrow$ q |
| T | T |  T  |
| T | F |  F  |
| F | T |  F  |
| F | F |  T  |
Logic: p if and only if q.

related_concepts.name: Equivalence
related_concepts.definition: Statement asserting that two propositions are logically identical.

subject: Math
title: Roots Relation
description: Sum and product of roots for $ax^2 + bx + c = 0$.
derivation:
Roots are $\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{D}}{2a}$.
Sum: $\frac{-b+\sqrt{D}}{2a} + \frac{-b-\sqrt{D}}{2a} = \frac{-2b}{2a} = -\frac{b}{a}$.
Product: $\frac{(-b)^2 - (\sqrt{D})^2}{4a^2} = \frac{b^2 - (b^2-4ac)}{4a^2} = \frac{4ac}{4a^2} = \frac{c}{a}$.

related_concepts.name: Newton's Sums
related_concepts.definition: $a S_n + b S_{n-1} + c S_{n-2} = 0$ where $S_n = \alpha^n + \beta^n$.

subject: Math
title: Nature of Roots
description: Discriminant determines the nature of roots.
derivation:
From Quadratic Formula $x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{D}}{2a}$:
1. $D > 0$: Two distinct real roots ($\pm$ gives diff values).
2. $D = 0$: Two equal real roots ($-b/2a$).
3. $D < 0$: Two complex conjugate roots ($\sqrt{-1} = i$).

related_concepts.name: Parabola Vertex
related_concepts.definition: The turning point of the graph is at $(-b/2a, -D/4a)$.

subject: Math
title: Condition for Common Root
description: Condition for one root common between $a_1x^2+b_1x+c_1=0$ and $a_2x^2+b_2x+c_2=0$.
derivation:
Let $\alpha$ be the common root.
$a_1 \alpha^2 + b_1 \alpha + c_1 = 0$
$a_2 \alpha^2 + b_2 \alpha + c_2 = 0$
Solve using Cramer's Rule (Cross-multiplication) for $\alpha^2$ and $\alpha$:
$\frac{\alpha^2}{b_1c_2-b_2c_1} = \frac{\alpha}{c_1a_2-c_2a_1} = \frac{1}{a_1b_2-a_2b_1}$.
Eliminate $\alpha$: $(\text{middle term})^2 = (\text{first})(\text{last})$.

related_concepts.name: Both Roots Common
related_concepts.definition: Condition: $\frac{a_1}{a_2} = \frac{b_1}{b_2} = \frac{c_1}{c_2}$.

subject: Math
title: Circular Permutation
description: Number of ways to arrange $n$ distinct objects in a circle.
derivation:
Linear arrangement of $n$ items = $n!$.
In a circle, shifting all items one step clockwise results in the same arrangement.
There are $n$ such rotational shifts for every linear arrangement.
Total distinct circular arrangements = $\frac{n!}{n} = (n-1)!$.

related_concepts.name: Necklace Problem
related_concepts.definition: If clockwise and anti-clockwise are same (flip allowed), $N = \frac{1}{2}(n-1)!$.

subject: Math
title: Derangements
description: Number of ways to arrange $n$ items such that none appears in its original position.
derivation:
Using Principle of Inclusion-Exclusion:
Total permutations = $n!$.
Subtract cases where at least 1 is fixed, add back 2 fixed, etc.
$D_n = n! - \binom{n}{1}(n-1)! + \binom{n}{2}(n-2)! - \dots$
$D_n = n! (1 - \frac{1}{1!} + \frac{1}{2!} - \frac{1}{3!} + \dots)$.

related_concepts.name: Approximation
related_concepts.definition: $D_n \approx \frac{n!}{e}$ (nearest integer).

subject: Math
title: Number of Divisors
description: Total divisors of $n = p_1^a p_2^b p_3^c...$ (prime factorization).
derivation:
A divisor is formed by selecting prime factors.
For $p_1^a$, we can select $p_1$ with powers $0, 1, 2, ..., a$ ($a+1$ choices).
For $p_2^b$, we have $b+1$ choices.
By Fundamental Principle of Counting, multiply choices.

subject: Math
title: Rolle's Theorem
description: If $f$ is continuous on $[a,b]$, differentiable on $(a,b)$, and $f(a)=f(b)$.
derivation:
If $f(a)=f(b)$ and the function is not constant, it must go up and come down (or vice versa).
At the turning point (peak or valley), the tangent must be horizontal.
Horizontal tangent $\implies$ Slope $f'(c) = 0$.

related_concepts.name: Stationary Point
related_concepts.definition: A point where the derivative of a function is zero.

subject: Math
title: Lagrange Mean Value Theorem (LMVT)
description: There exists $c \in (a,b)$ where tangent slope equals secant slope.
derivation:
Generalization of Rolle's Theorem.
Consider the secant line joining $A(a, f(a))$ and $B(b, f(b))$. Slope = $\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}$.
As you move along the curve from A to B, at some point the tangent must be parallel to this chord.
Parallel lines have equal slopes.

related_concepts.name: Average Rate of Change
related_concepts.definition: The slope of the secant line, representing average velocity/rate.

subject: Math
title: Second Derivative Test
description: Test for local extrema at critical point $c$ where $f'(c)=0$.
derivation:
1. If $f''(c) < 0$, the graph is Concave Down (frowning).
   A flat tangent ($f'=0$) on a frown must be a peak (Maxima).
2. If $f''(c) > 0$, the graph is Concave Up (smiling).
   A flat tangent on a smile must be a bottom (Minima).

related_concepts.name: Concavity
related_concepts.definition: Direction of curvature. $f'' > 0$ is convex (up), $f'' < 0$ is concave (down).

subject: Math
title: Integral of ln(x)
visual_data: \int \ln x dx = x \ln x - x + C
description: Standard result derived using Integration by Parts.
derivation:
Use Parts with $u = \ln x$ and $dv = 1 dx$.
$du = \frac{1}{x} dx, v = x$.
Formula: $\int u dv = uv - \int v du$.
$I = x \ln x - \int x (\frac{1}{x}) dx = x \ln x - \int 1 dx$.
$I = x \ln x - x$.

related_concepts.definition: Using 1 as the second function is a common trick for inverse and log functions.

subject: Math
title: Gamma Function
description: Generalization of factorial. $\Gamma(n) = (n-1)!$ for integer $n$.
derivation:
Using Integration by Parts on $\Gamma(n+1) = \int e^{-x} x^n dx$.
$I = [-x^n e^{-x}]_0^\infty + n \int e^{-x} x^{n-1} dx$.
Boundary term vanishes.
$I = n \Gamma(n)$.
This recursive property mimics factorial ($n! = n(n-1)!$).

related_concepts.name: Half Integer Gamma
related_concepts.definition: $\Gamma(1/2) = \sqrt{\pi}$.

subject: Math
title: Multinomial Theorem
description: General term in expansion of $(x_1 + x_2 + \dots + x_k)^n$.
derivation:
Combinatorial logic:
We need to arrange $n$ brackets.
We select $x_1$ from $n_1$ brackets, $x_2$ from $n_2$ brackets, etc.
Total permutations of $n$ items where $n_1$ are identical type 1, etc., is $\frac{n!}{n_1! n_2! \dots}$.

related_concepts.name: Permutations with Repetition
related_concepts.definition: Arranging objects where some are identical.

subject: Math
title: Linear Dependence
description: Vectors are dependent if one can be written as combination of others (Coplanar/Collinear).
derivation:
If three vectors are linearly dependent, they lie in the same plane (for 3 vectors).
Thus, the volume of the parallelepiped formed by them is zero.
Condition: Scalar Triple Product $[\vec{a} \vec{b} \vec{c}] = 0$.
Algebraically: Determinant of coefficients is zero.

related_concepts.name: Basis
related_concepts.definition: A set of linearly independent vectors that span a space.

subject: Math
title: Orthogonal Trajectory
description: Family of curves intersecting given family at right angles.
derivation:
1. Form differential equation of given family: $f(x, y, y') = 0$.
2. Condition for orthogonality: Product of slopes $m_1 m_2 = -1$.
   So, replace $y'$ with $-1/y'$.
3. Solve the new Differential Equation to get the orthogonal family.

related_concepts.name: Equipotential Lines
related_concepts.definition: Orthogonal trajectories to electric field lines.

subject: Math
title: Telescoping Series
description: Summation method where intermediate terms cancel out.
derivation:
Write out terms:
$T_1 = f(1) - f(2)$
$T_2 = f(2) - f(3)$
$T_3 = f(3) - f(4)$
Adding them: $-f(2)$ and $+f(2)$ cancel, etc.
Only the first part of first term and last part of last term survive.
Sum $= f(1) - f(n+1)$.

related_concepts.name: Partial Fractions
related_concepts.definition: Used to split rational terms into differences for telescoping.

subject: Math
title: Inverse Function Existence
description: A function has an inverse iff it is One-One and Onto.
derivation:
1. One-One (Injection): Ensures $f^{-1}$ maps an output back to a *unique* input.
2. Onto (Surjection): Ensures $f^{-1}$ is defined for *all* elements in the codomain.
Graphically: Passes Horizontal Line Test.

related_concepts.name: Horizontal Line Test
related_concepts.definition: A geometric test to determine if a function is one-to-one.

subject: Math
title: m-n Theorem
description: Relates segments of the base of a triangle to the angles.
derivation:
In $\Delta ABC$, point D divides BC in ratio $m:n$. $\theta = \angle ADC$.
Apply Sine Rule in $\Delta ABD$ and $\Delta ACD$.
$m/\sin B = AD/\sin(\theta-\alpha)$ and $n/\sin C = AD/\sin(180-\theta-\beta)$.
Divide equations and expand sin terms to derive the relation.

related_concepts.name: Appollonius Theorem
related_concepts.definition: Can be derived as a special case where $m=n$ (Median).
